comment: Select an App where you can start to explore Vega Charting...
Search for the Vega HowTo Screen and add it to your App...
Vega Charting is enabled through a Web Component...
Make sure that the vega-component is selected in your App...
Now let's start editing the Vega HowTo Screen...
The vega-component has some built-in Guidance presenting some useful links...
An important resource is the Vega Example Gallery (as well as the Vega-Lite Example Gallery...
Let's start with the Basics and pick a simple Bar Chart to explore...
Vega Charts are based on JSON specifications and the Vega Editor allows you to understand things work...
Without trying to understand Vega right now, let's just COPY a Specification to the Clipboard...
Now let's edit a Remix Function which has been configured to feed a Vega Specification into the vega-component...
Just PASTE the Vega Specification into the Function Body and return to the Screen Layout...
We now have a Vega Chart viewable within a Remix Screen...
Now let's go back in and make a modification to the Vega Specification...
We are going to remove the Data which was embedded in the Specification...
The results of doing this is clear.  We not longer see Bars in the Chart just the X and Y axes...
Now let's edit a Remix Function which has been configured to feed Data into the vega-component...
Data for Vega Charts typically is an Array of Object.  So let's make sure we the JSON for the Data is valid...
We now see how a Vega Specification combined with dynamic data renders a Chart...
See how we've configured the Output of the Function to bind to the vegaData Property...
And the Output of the first Function is bound to the vegaSpec Property...
